title: Drake Maye says marrying young was ‘one of the best things I’ve experienced in my life’
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Drake Maye shared on Instagram that marrying young was a significant and positive decision in his life.
New England Patriots quarterback Maye married Ann Michael on June 21, 2025, in North Carolina.
Maye and his wife began dating in middle school, maintaining their relationship through high school and college.

title: 23 queer romance books perfect for Valentine’s Day reading
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Boston.com releases a queer romance book guide for Valentine's Day with recommendations fitting various tastes.
The guide features 23 queer romance novels categorized by spice level and tone, from mild to spicy and light to dark.
Genres include gothic, sports rivalries, and historical romances, catering to both intense and sweet romantic preferences.

title: Will Campbell talks poor Super Bowl performance, avoiding media, and more
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Will Campbell allowed 14 pressures in Super Bowl LX, the most by any player in a single game this NFL season.
After avoiding media following the Patriots' Super Bowl loss, Campbell apologized and discussed the emotional toll of the defeat.
Coach Mike Vrabel confirmed Campbell will remain the Patriots' left tackle despite his struggles and media speculation about a position change.

title: Mike Vrabel on the Patriots’ foundation, his view of the 2025 season, and Will Campbell’s future
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Patriots head coach Mike Vrabel discusses the team's foundation and learning to win despite Super Bowl LX loss to Seahawks.
Vrabel confirms Will Campbell remains the Patriots' left tackle, dismissing calls to move him to guard despite Super Bowl struggles.
Defensive coordinator Terrell Williams to return after cancer absence; future role of Zak Kuhr remains unresolved.

title: Boston to host FIFA World Cup Fan Fest at City Hall Plaza
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Boston's City Hall Plaza will host the FIFA World Cup Fan Festival in 2026, announced by Mayor Michelle Wu.
Governor Maura Healey expects over 2 million international visitors, contributing to a $1 billion economic impact.
The World Cup will include seven matches at Gillette Stadium, projected to generate $100 million in tax revenue.

title: Are MBTA commuters destined to suffer for the rest of the winter?
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: MBTA General Manager Phil Eng assures improvements despite challenges from frigid weather causing delays and cancellations this winter.
Oldest Red Line cars are kept in service to meet demand, causing longer wait times due to winter conditions.
MBTA implements solutions like crib heaters and indoor storage to mitigate winter weather disruptions on service.

title: Wu says she would vote for statewide rent control through proposed ballot question
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston Mayor Michelle Wu supports a proposed ballot measure for statewide rent control, despite preferring a local option.
The proposed measure caps annual rent increases at cost of living changes, with a maximum increase of 5%.
Opposition includes Governor Maura Healey and real estate industry figures, who argue rent control could harm housing construction.

title: Christian Gonzalez on Patriots extension talks: ‘I don’t want to be anywhere else’
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Christian Gonzalez, Patriots cornerback, is eligible for a contract extension this offseason, which he is open to signing.
Gonzalez had a strong performance in Super Bowl LX, with three pass breakups against the Seattle Seahawks.
The Patriots can extend Gonzalez's contract or exercise a fifth-year option, delaying his free agency until 2028.

title: Man dies after being struck by MBTA commuter rail train in Haverhill
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: A man died after being struck by an MBTA train in Haverhill early Tuesday morning, officials said.
The man intentionally entered the right of way near the Cross Street crossing before the incident occurred.
The incident caused significant train delays on the Haverhill Line with normal service resuming around 8:30 a.m.

title: Boston Raising Cane’s faces eviction over chicken finger odor, lawsuit says
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Raising Cane's in Boston is facing eviction over chicken finger odor claims by its landlord, 755 Boylston, LLC.
The lawsuit alleges the landlord seeks to cancel Raising Cane's exclusive chicken restaurant rights to allow a Panda Express.
Raising Cane's has spent over $200,000 on odor mitigation and is suing for breach of lease and monetary damages.
